statement.p: Instructions call for producing a solution of amoxicillin that contains 250 g of the provided dry solute with 5 mL of sterile water. What is the
dilution ratio: Preview Question 1 Part 1 of 3
dilution factor: Preview Question 1 Part 2 of 3
percent concentration: Preview Question 1 Part 3 of 3

solution.p: We use the definitions for solutions of dry ingredients in a solution.
The dilution ratio is defined to be grams of solute per mL of diluent added. We have 250 g of solute with 5 mL of diluent added, so the ratio is 250/5.

The dilution factor is defined to be grams of solute per mL of solution resulting. We have 250 g of solute in 5 mL of diluent, so the ratio is 250/5. Sometimes it is written as simply 5. Note, this matches dilution ratio because the solute adds almost no volume to the solution (too small to measure).

The percent concentration is defined to be grams of solute per mL of solution resulting written as a percent. We have 250 g of solute in 5 mL of diluent, so the percent is \displaystyle\frac{{250}}{{5}}\cdot{100}={5000}\%.
